metadata.description: Comprehensive guidance for international students (F-1, M-1, J-1), including visa, SEVIS, I-20, financial aid, employment, scholarships, travel, and compliance.

categories.title: SEVIS System Overview
categories.description: Information about the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) and the Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP).

content_blocks.text: SEVIS is the web-based system used by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security to maintain information on nonimmigrant students (F-1 and M-1) and exchange visitors (J-1).

text: Monitors student and exchange visitor status.
Tracks Form I-20 and DSOs.
Ensures compliance with visa regulations.

content_blocks.text: All SEVP-certified schools must use SEVIS to report student enrollment and status changes.
SEVP certifies U.S. schools to enroll nonimmigrant students and maintain compliance with federal regulations.

text: Community colleges, universities, vocational schools may be certified.
DSOs are responsible for accurate reporting of student data.
Annual verification is required to maintain certification.

categories.title: Student Visas and Status
categories.description: Details on F-1, M-1, J-1 visa types and maintenance of legal status, including change of status and dependent visas.

content_blocks.text: F-1 is the visa for academic students attending universities, colleges, or English language programs in the U.S.

text: Requires full-time enrollment.
Eligible for on-campus employment and certain practical training.
Dependent F-2 visas for spouse and children.

content_blocks.text: M-1 is the visa for students attending vocational or non-academic programs.

text: Full-time enrollment required for the program duration.
Employment is limited; only practical training allowed after program completion.
Dependent M-2 visas for spouse and children.

content_blocks.text: J-1 is the visa for exchange visitors participating in approved programs such as research, teaching, or cultural exchange.

text: Program sponsor must be approved by the U.S. Department of State.
Duration varies based on program.
Dependent J-2 visas are available for spouse and children.

content_blocks.text: Students in the U.S. may apply to change their visa status (e.g., B-2 to F-1) using Form I-539.

text: F-1 and M-1 eligibility requirements must be met.
Gap bridging rules apply for M-1 students.
B-1/B-2 to F-1 change requires evidence of intent to study full-time.
H-1B status change may require additional documentation.

categories.title: Form I-20
categories.description: Certificate of Eligibility for Nonimmigrant Student Status, required for F-1/M-1 visa and entry to the U.S.

content_blocks.text: Form I-20 is issued by a SEVP-certified school to eligible F-1 or M-1 students. It allows payment of the SEVIS I-901 fee, visa application, and entry to the U.S.

text: Contains student information, program of study, and school info.
Signed by the Designated School Official (DSO).
Required for travel, visa application, and work authorization.

topics.title: Requesting a New or Replacement I-20

content_blocks.text: Students may request a new Form I-20 when changing programs, extending their study, or replacing a lost or damaged form.

text: Submit request to your DSO.
Provide supporting documentation (new program info, updated financials).
Sign the form upon receipt, especially if traveling internationally.

categories.title: I-901 SEVIS Fee
categories.description: Payment of the SEVIS I-901 fee required for all F-1 and M-1 students.

content_blocks.text: The I-901 SEVIS Fee must be paid before applying for a visa or entering the U.S.

text: Payment via FMJfee.com using SEVIS ID from Form I-20.
Fee varies depending on visa type: F-1 ($350), M-1 ($220).
Keep receipt for visa interview and U.S. entry.

content_blocks.text: Students exempt from the fee or changing status may have special instructions.

categories.title: Travel and Entry
categories.description: Guidance for entering the U.S., including required documentation, Form I-94, and reporting requirements.

content_blocks.text: International students must present valid visa, passport, and Form I-20 at the port of entry.

text: Form I-94 is issued electronically; retain for records.
Arrive within 30 days of program start date.
Secondary inspection may occur if documentation is incomplete (Form I-515A).
Report to school by program start date.

categories.title: Programs of Study
categories.description: Overview of academic and vocational programs available for international students.

content_blocks.text: F-1 students may enroll in community colleges, undergraduate, or graduate programs at SEVP-certified institutions.

text: STEM programs are eligible for OPT extensions.
English language programs may be full-time or part-time.
Vocational programs fall under M-1 classification.

categories.title: Practical Training and Employment
categories.description: Work authorization options for international students during and after their studies.

content_blocks.text: CPT allows F-1 students to engage in employment directly related to their major field of study before graduation.

text: Eligibility: Must have completed one academic year (exceptions for graduate programs).
Part-time CPT: 20 hours/week or less during school session.
Full-time CPT: More than 20 hours/week, may affect eligibility for OPT.
Requires DSO authorization on Form I-20.
Employer and job must be integral to the curriculum.

content_blocks.text: OPT allows F-1 students to work in the U.S. in their field of study for up to 12 months after graduation.

text: Application: File Form I-765 with USCIS.
Eligibility: Must complete at least one academic year.
Timeline: Apply up to 90 days before graduation, no later than 60 days after program end.
Unemployment: Limited to 90 days for regular OPT, extended for STEM OPT.
Reporting: Must report employer information and address updates to DSO.

content_blocks.text: STEM OPT allows eligible STEM graduates to extend their OPT by 24 months.

text: Eligibility: Degree in approved STEM fields, employer must be E-Verify registered.
Form I-983 Training Plan required.
Application: File Form I-765 before regular OPT expires.
Second extension: Only if another qualifying STEM degree is earned.
Reporting: Regular validation reports every 6 months and annual self-evaluation.

categories.title: Scholarships and Financial Aid
categories.description: Financial resources for international students, including merit-based, country-specific, and institutional programs.

content_blocks.text: A curated list of 137 scholarship opportunities for international students covering multiple degree levels and countries.
Details include eligibility, award amount, application deadlines, and provider contact information wherever available.

text: Assistantships and fellowships for graduate students.
Grants from universities or governments.
Loans available for international students from select institutions.
Need-based institutional aid.

categories.title: Student Life Cycle and Compliance
categories.description: Guidance on maintaining status, reporting, and other obligations throughout the student lifecycle.

content_blocks.text: Maintaining F-1 or M-1 status is critical for lawful presence and future benefits.

text: Enroll full-time every semester (exceptions require DSO authorization).
Report changes of address or personal information within 10 days.
Apply for program extensions before current end date.
Reinstatement: If status is violated, file Form I-539 and follow USCIS procedures.
Grace periods: 60 days for F-1, 30 days for M-1 post-completion.

content_blocks.text: International students working on-campus or authorized off-campus must obtain an SSN for tax and employment purposes.

text: Apply at local SSA office with passport, I-94, visa, and I-20.
Provide job offer letter if on-campus employment.
Processing may take 2â€“4 weeks.
Use SSN for payroll, banking, and tax purposes.

content_blocks.text: International students may have federal and state tax obligations, even if income is limited.

text: File Form 8843 for all F/M visa holders.
File Form 1040NR if earned U.S. income.
Use ITIN if SSN is unavailable.
Check for tax treaties between home country and U.S.

content_blocks.text: Health insurance is often mandatory and ensures access to medical care.

text: Check if school provides a plan; enroll if required.
Private insurance is allowed if coverage meets minimum standards.
ACA marketplace plans may not satisfy requirements.
Keep documentation for visa compliance and emergencies.

content_blocks.text: Students may face emergencies affecting status, legal issues, or health.

text: Status violations: Contact DSO immediately.
Reinstatement: File Form I-539 if out of status.
Emergency contacts: School, embassy, local authorities.
Keep records of all communications and documentation.
